body:
Indeed, it appears to be good as is. 

P.S. If there are still concerns about the minimisation issue while running from the terminal, given that it may generally manifest with development builds in practice, adding a comment or logging may be considered. (e.g. minimised during development -> info in console)
Thanks!

Thanks for the suggested testing option and further investigation. I had a quick look at the implementation of `org.eclipse.jgit.transport.URIish`. If I'm not mistaken it has a to optimistic interpretation of what is allowed in an URL (at least the variant defined in RFC2396, which java.net.URI is modelled after).
I'll investigate further and see if I can find a fix, that will be accepted by jgit.

I added another commit which removes the branch filter of the toolbar. The reason for that is essentially https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/6594 which never got fully resolved.

The branch filter in the toolbar filtered the results _after_ the `git log` command ran. This requires to have all branch information in the revisions, if some branches are missing, it is likely that the filter will remove too many commits (it often would show no results at all in larger repos). Removing the branch filter fixes it.

Secondly: there is a second branch filter in the search options section which runs _during_ `git log` and is therefore not affected. Having two branch filters in the same UI is also a bit questionable, it confused me quite often tbh even when it worked. The typical usecase is to view the history of the checked out branch which is the default anyway.

toolbar branch filter removed with search section expanded:
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/5995cf91-068d-4725-ba98-acb596b0a3bd)
Its a long time bug, also appears the same randomization when switching project groups, or after version upgrade.
First test result: If you don't use the http transport, but the SSH transport, it works without problems.

Hi, I'm not sure how to reproduce this issue. I encounter some graphical glitches on wsl2 (ubuntu) on other application and was more or less solved updating wsl. 

`wsl.exe --update `

To get the pre-release you could try this
`wsl.exe --update --pre-release ` 

Could you eventually share wsl --version output ? (executed from powershell) 
```
Version WSL : 2.0.14.0
Version du noyau : 5.15.133.1-1
Version WSLg : 1.0.59
Version MSRDC : 1.2.4677
Version direct3D : 1.611.1-81528511
Version de DXCore : 10.0.25131.1002-220531-1700.rs-onecore-base2-hyp
Version de Windows : 10.0.19045.4170
```

Hi sorry to join late. But **${revision}** is reserved word, if **${my-revision}** were used it's should warn that version is incorrect

${revision}, ${changelist}, and ${sha1} are the reserved versions as per https://maven.apache.org/docs/3.2.1/release-notes.html
Oh sorry I didn't knew of this. So, anything apart from ${revision}, ${changelist}, and ${sha1} cannot be used as expression in version field?

I'm not aware of others 'keyword' but if you use a random properties you will have warning

```
Some problems were encountered while building the effective model for com.mycompany:mavenproject2:pom:${sha1aa}
'version' contains an expression but should be a constant. @ line 6, column 14

It is highly recommended to fix these problems because they threaten the stability of your build.

For this reason, future Maven versions might no longer support building such malformed projects.
```

Yes, valid properties from here I think - https://github.com/apache/maven/blob/master/maven-model-builder/src/main/java/org/apache/maven/model/interpolation/DefaultModelVersionProcessor.java#L43  Not sure best way to access that, or whether to code in the allowed values?
maybe hardcoded + link to the github :p
thanks for the reviews so far, planning to merge this Sunday evening UTC.

Thank you. The problem was reproducible and the core information missing above is, that this happens for java projects without ties to a concrete server/without explicit JPA support. I created a PR that should fix that (see link above).

Please test if the nightly build fixes the issue for you (it will be available for the next 4 days):

- Overview page: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions/runs/8302458674
- Direct link: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions/runs/8302458674/artifacts/1330914673

sorry that I change things after it was already reviewed but I found a few more things to do after debugging.

When looking through `IncludeExclude` (which is a quite risky implementation), I noticed that the class isn't called at all. Turns out that the whole https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/bbd18aa9369eca4d8c32e6ffab29940347d260a4/nb/o.n.upgrader/src/org/netbeans/upgrade/Copy.java#L33 class isn't used.

`AutoUpgrade` (the entry point) is only using `CopyFiles`. and once its done [`Importer`](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/7d861a393f7168025386174baeb495353b3759fc/nb/o.n.upgrader/src/org/netbeans/upgrade/systemoptions/Importer.java) is called. `CopyFiles` has its own implementation of the import/exclude logic.

now the question is: should we remove more?
`Copy`, `IncludeExclude`, `PathTransformation`+ tests?

Or merge as is?

Hi @matthiasblaesing 
I can confirm that with development version there is no errors (my test was : open / edit / close / re-open all .xhtml files in my project).

Thanks.
I am thinking that I am going to merge leave the other cleanup options for future PRs.

> * When child pom uses variable again for the parent version then it throws false error: > ![image](https://private-user-images.githubusercontent.com/55803675/312801665-05103a54-04b0-4773-9778-488d1eaaef96.png?jwt=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..q6S4HRUNNi5bFFn22Sn8jkcczUUIKF9y-51_sj4NGnI) > > So, fixed the above mentioned issue in this PR. Refer for more info: [oracle/javavscode#95](https://github.com/oracle/javavscode/issues/95) The above error is anyways misleading for any case. So, imo we can keep the change that is done in this PR as it is. Since, warning is already shown if something other than these 3 keywords are used in the `version` tag, isn't it correct?
this is causing graal tests to fail since they run on EOL JDK 11 graalvm, but I think i found a way to temp fix this without revert. Testing it locally atm.

to add a bit more info for anyone who is interested in this:
 - we might start to disable modules to be able to keep the polyglot tests active for a while longer (https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7169)
 - graalvm deployment changed, additional languages are not installed via `gu` "into" the JDK, they are regular dependencies for the application (https://github.com/oracle/graal/issues/6852)
   - even though this happened in GraalVM 21, 17 does not seem to have any language extensions (`$bin/gu available`) for some reason, I don't know why. 
     edit: GraalVM 17 v22.3.1 was the last known release which had all language extensions available, tests are using this build now https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/1a4519c40243e3556209286159bb9c3d7704e135/.github/workflows/main.yml#L2582-L2584
   - i am not looking forward to making lib wrapper modules for them just for the tests, maybe there is a way to avoid this and keep them in the env somehow (jlink a custom jdk for the workflow? find a dist which includes all?)
 - to make the graal tests build/run from within NB while using GraalVM CE, i had to remove the `<copy todir="${jpda.classes.dir}">` sections in `java/api.debugger.jpda/build.xml, java/debugger`.`jpda.truffle/build.xml` and `java/debugger.jpda/build.xml`
@dbalek please wait with more merges until the graal job is working again, thanks!
Makes sense to me. I'm still wondering whether project galahad (integration of java parts of graalvm into OpenJDK) will happen or if it will suffer the same fate as nashorn.
refreshing PR and preparing for merge

 - root repo is found by probing remotes in this order: `origin4nb`, `upstream`, `origin`, `origin/HEAD` and then anything starting with `origin/`

I really like the idea of doing this, but the implementation here obviously has some issues, and the hardcoded choices are a problem for the platform.  Have had a look at doing something similar to @matthiasblaesing suggestion, but using action lookup rather than allowing for registering any component.

Only eyeballed this, but the decoupling looks like what I had in mind. This approach is more focused than what I thought about, but also looks sane.

I noticed that you invented your own stringification algorithm for the keystrokes. I assume, that you don't use `Utilities.keyToString` directly because you don't agree with the stringification it creates?

A question that came to my mind: how does the list react when it becomes to large for the window? Reason could be because the user resized it so small or because the list is just long.
Thank you for the correction, I fixed the original text to reflect your note. Thank you
Please help, this situation is extremely painful. Thank you

Well the last commit forces to use sigtest to generate signatures without recursion.

That behavior was fixed in the commit mentioned above, so that commit is just keeping the same wrong way of doing the things as before.
going to merge so that I can easier test interactions with a rebased #7128

looks clean and has potential for more!

> Utilities.keyToString

Interesting - I didn't know that this existed, I actually searched for this yesterday since I wanted to add hotkeys to the tooltip of some toolbar buttons for #7128. Refactoring, quick search UI etc simply puts the default hotkeys into the bundle text - which isn't ideal.
rebasing/squashing for a fresh run and preparing for merge

I looked through [com.sun.tools.javac.tree.Pretty](https://github.com/openjdk/jdk/blob/jdk-22%2B36/src/jdk.compiler/share/classes/com/sun/tools/javac/tree/Pretty.java) which is called by `JCTree#toString` and I think it should be fine to call `TreePath#toString` lazily on EDT -> merging once green again

> Only eyeballed this, but the decoupling looks like what I had in mind. This approach is more focused than what I thought about, but also looks sane.

Thanks.  I realised if we went for registering background components, we'd still need to also register the actions for that component somewhere.  There are benefits to having action display directly in the module, but that doesn't mean we couldn't extend to support other components later too.
 
> I noticed that you invented your own stringification algorithm for the keystrokes. I assume, that you don't use `Utilities.keyToString` directly because you don't agree with the stringification it creates?

Actually I copied that from KeyStrokeUtils in options.keymap (as commented).  `Utilities::keyToString` isn't really user friendly for this - eg. `DS-O` vs `Ctrl+Shift+O`.  I was thinking that we needed a utility API that provides the text you'd see in the menu, etc.  Just having another look, I realised that's already available in `Actions::keyStrokeToString`.  I've updated the PR to use that instead.

> A question that came to my mind: how does the list react when it becomes to large for the window? Reason could be because the user resized it so small or because the list is just long.

The image disappears first, then the list will just get hidden.  I thought about limiting the number of actions, but I'm not sure that's needed as and until we provide a UI to customise.  The window needs to be small enough to be unusable for the six registered here not to be in view.

```
Product Version: Apache NetBeans IDE 21
Java: 11.0.22; OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM 11.0.22+7-post-Ubuntu-0ubuntu220.04.1
Runtime: OpenJDK Runtime Environment 11.0.22+7-post-Ubuntu-0ubuntu220.04.1
System: Linux version 5.4.0-173-generic running on amd64; UTF-8; en_US (nb)
```

there might be ways to improve this if there is a missing cancel check somewhere, but there is no good defense against bad regexps.
There is a reason why they are such popular entry point for DOS attacks. If your regexp matches against the whole file it won't stop until the file is processed - this won't be a problem for most expressions as long they are somewhat efficient since a single file is typically processed in much less than a second.
The search should be always done in a separate thread and such thread should be possible to stop anytime.
threads can't be stopped so easily, it is a bit more involved than that.

Updated the code based on comments.

> no shortcut assigned doesn't fit here well with the new layout. Maybe just n/a will also be fine?

I'm not sure anything with letters works very well.  Anyway, I've updated to make the no-shortcut label brandable.  Empty by default in the platform, set to `-` currently in the IDE.  So like second screenshot above.

I've used the bundle from the ui package for this, because if we extend this further the background component should probably move into there.

> In fact I like it so much that I think we should consider to switch the auto-open of the start page off by default 

Added extra commit to do that.  As said in the main description, I've started looking at some sort of dashboard API for the platform which has overlap with the welcome page.  The welcome page is showing its age and a lot of the content isn't that useful any more.

> The nb logo should have a purpose too! Could it open the about window?

We could consider extending to do that later.  Can we leave until NB23+?  I've reused (and added a fix) to the existing image support in this.  I don't know if anyone is using the `netbeans.winsys.imageSource` property as specified in https://bits.netbeans.org/dev/javadoc/org-openide-windows/overview-summary.html#group-systemproperty  

> what do you think about adding a Project Groups... button below Open Project...?

Was top of my list of actions I left out.  Came very close to adding it.  Possibly too advanced for the beginner, and not the most useful place for a regular NetBeans user?

> Was top of my list of actions I left out. Came very close to adding it. Possibly too advanced for the beginner, and not the most useful place for a regular NetBeans user?

you are probably right. Once a user starts using PGs its likely that he/she won't see that panel very often unless maybe when switching to the `none` group.

regarding usefulness for beginners: well a beginner could also be someone who knows many IDEs already but checked out NB for the first time.

Hello, I also have tis problem, but it doesn't work even after installind JDK20.
I think there is some garbage on windows. I cannot find any solution. That's very annoying.
Is there any help?

I also see the most common actions as a priority here. I also find it useful to see that we can drag a file or folder to the empty place to open this folder as a "project" but maybe also not that necessary. To add. Maybe also the quick search would be good to catch. Maybe later if we refactor this also :D.

I would suggest to have it like this, all other stuff we should add to a redesigned welcome page.
LGTM with my limited understanding

> I would suggest to have it like this, all other stuff we should add to a redesigned welcome page.

My goal with this and any dashboard API would be to make these elements foreground common tasks for beginners, seasoned users and people who have experience of other IDEs.

Both should eventually be customizable via UI, and usable in platform applications too (which is part of my reason for working on it at the moment).

A Project Group widget on a dashboard might make more sense than an action here.

The Quick Search action is the only action with a shortcut already on display, and invoking the action directly by clicking is not that useful.  Labels for eg. drag-n-drop need a little thought with this implementation.  I wonder if there's an easily understandable icon for that - could add below logo?

Hello,

import.meta.url / import.meta.resolve is the only way to solve some `path` issues.

Please prioritize this !

Thank you

The idea to add common actions with shortcuts to the editor background is quite convenient. Additionally, would it be feasible to incorporate action icons (from menus/toolbars), as this may provide added benefits for beginners? Here is a mockup what it might look like: Considering that this is the editor background, to enhance its lightweight appearance, while ensuring visual distinction from the toolbar, icons may be semi-transparent. Another consideration, albeit it may be deemed excessive, is the inclusion of recent files and projects. This would facilitate quick and easy access, as users presently must navigate menus or open the Welcome screen and select the appropriate tab. If ever implemented, it could potentially display the latest 3-4 items, whereas the menus and Welcome screen may accommodate a greater number of items.

@mhalachev thanks for your suggestions.  Firstly, I deliberately left out the icons after trying it.  It looked better without, although I do understand your point about teaching new users what the icons mean.  Perhaps something to revisit in another iteration, if we can keep the visual impact down.

Secondly, the Recent Projects and Recent Files sections are similar to what I had in mind for a dashboard to replace the welcome screen.  The background area is only rarely on display - a dashboard accessible from more places could better display those things IMO.
What you're describing already exists. You want to look at the Project Groups option.
Anyone, a word? I'm about to merge this one today or tomorrow, as #7024 is depending on this one.
@matthiasblaesing thanks for your feedback!
It seems our `ValidateClassFilesTest` is complaining about `languages/toml` not being marked as Java 11. Will fix as time permits.

things I haven't implemented:
 - I wanted to add file type icons to the diff view but couldn't find an elegant way of doing this
 - diff view file name column has no quicksearch highlighting due to the way how the tree works, I left a comment in-code
 - I haven't touched the file history window at all otherwise this PR would be too large. It doesn't listen to hotkeys etc. (NB has too many diff windows!)
 - UI persistence. Layout and table column settings are not persisted.
added all-tests label just to be sure. If it was green once, feel free to remove it again.

delete-artifact action succeeded in https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions/runs/8401048380?pr=7181
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/73449028-048a-4dce-a7cc-c06fea9abf5b)

Yep, I've also added two more images to `licenseinfo.xml`, and updated `javac.target` in antlr4 runtime lib (antlr4.13.1 is compiled with JDK11). Let's see how it goes with full tests now.
would it make sense to open a meta issue afterwards which has a list of all mods where sig tests are turned off so that we can look that up when needed?
all green!

> Keeps the existing `ide/tomlj`, that should be marked as deprecated (how is this done?) and possibly removed in the future.

I am not sure but probably over the module manifest, example:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/306f174318db1e1d5fbe7a63d827d66c7a38978d/ide/o.openidex.util/manifest.mf#L5-L6

I believe this will cause a warning during module load.
So let's deprectate `libs.tomlj` then. It's currently used in the `rust` cluster only and will be replaced later on (and possibly by platform users).
this is probably going to save someone's homework :)
The build is finally green now. If no one objects, I'm going to merge this tomorrow!
glad to see more cleanups, fits right into the theme of https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/6994 + https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/6987
planning to merge this soon since last time the JDK EA builds disappeared shortly after GA released which caused CI to fail.

@mhalachev I also like this and I see it the same way as @neilcsmith-net. It would be like a little wizard/startpage/dashboard. The empty editor is not that often empty. For example when you reopen your projects, you need to close all of them. The dashboard is smth that you can reopen it and also to set the option to show it everytime on startup or whatever. Keep it simple here for the empty editor pane.

I have some notes on document groups somewhere. One day I might try to make them work a bit better with project groups since right now they are not very useful in the current state (and they are slow) - stashing a doc group would lead right to the empty editor background, so assuming it works we might see that panel more often.

There are a few places in the IDE where the ANTLR generated java files are in the codebase. These are not re-generated during build time. and would cause warnings on the output:
```
ANTLR Tool version 4.11.1 used for code generation does not match the current runtime version 4.13.1
```

Fortunately it's nothing more serious than that this time.

Affected languages, that I remember: ANTLR v3, ANTLR v4, Go, JSON, maybe CSS

good that you mentioned this since this reminded me of the note on the [antlr4 page](https://github.com/antlr/antlr4?tab=readme-ov-file#versioning):
 >- minor version updates may include minor breaking changes, the policy is to regenerate parsers with every release (4.11 -> 4.12)
> - backwards compatibility is only guaranteed for patch version bumps (4.11.1 -> 4.11.2)

so the antlr3 (3.5.2->3.5.3) update was a patch update and should be fine, however the antlr4 (4.11.1->4.13.1) update might need regen.
Referencing the previous upgrade from 4.7.2 -> 4.11.1 #4845

I guess that the case is that you already have more often document tabs instead of closing all documents or closing a whole group. I will not say, that this case will never happen for someone but how often do you all see the empty editor background in your daily work from using NetBeans every day? I also haven't seen it in vs code. And this thing worked for years for the most IDEs. Yes, we can change things comparing to other IDEs and don't do the exact same, but we should do it not in the wrong way IMHO. The empty editor background should be just for the common stuff for opening the IDE once after new installation, remove the empty editor or in rare other cases.

A dashboard with more stuff like seeing tutorials, some common actions (similar to the empty editor background), recent projets/project groups, etc. is a better use case for a dashboard/startpage that you can always show on startup or before NetBeans starts a little simple dashboard before opening everything in NetBeans to change your case. My 2 cents.
